articles.headline: Chinese Goods May Face 25% Tariffs, Not 10%, as Trump’s Anger Grows
articles.snippet: The administration said it would consider raising proposed tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese products to 25 percent from 10 percent as China’s currency declines.
articles.abstract: The administration said it would consider raising proposed tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese products to 25 percent from 10 percent as China’s currency declines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump escalated his trade war with China on Wednesday, ordering his administration to consider more than doubling proposed tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods to 25 percent from 10 percent, as talks between Washington and Beijing remain at a standstill.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Google, Seeking a Return to China, Is Said to Be Building a Censored Search Engine
articles.snippet: Google withdrew from China in 2010 to protest the country’s censorship. Now the internet giant is working on a search engine that complies with Chinese censorship rules.
articles.abstract: Google withdrew from China in 2010 to protest the country’s censorship. Now the internet giant is working on a search engine that complies with Chinese censorship rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Google withdrew from China eight years ago to protest the country’s censorship and online hacking. Now, the internet giant is working on a censored search engine for China that will filter websites and search terms that are blacklisted by the Chinese government, according to two people with knowledge of the plans.
articles.byline: By Li Yuan and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Facing Losses, Condé Nast Plans to Put 3 Magazines Up for Sale
articles.snippet: Anna Wintour is staying, but the once-flush company behind Vogue and The New Yorker lost roughly $120 million last year.
articles.abstract: Anna Wintour is staying, but the once-flush company behind Vogue and The New Yorker lost roughly $120 million last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Condé Nast, the company behind Vogue, Vanity Fair and The New Yorker, became one of the most successful magazine publishers by charming readers and advertisers alike with a formula built on old-world glamour and all-American pizazz. But now, even after having taken measures to cut spending and make itself more digitally savvy, the company is expected to adopt a more radical strategy to ensure that it does not fade away.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Pennsylvania Diocese Orders Removal of Former Bishops’ Names From Church Buildings
articles.snippet: The move by a Harrisburg bishop comes ahead of a grand jury report expected to expose decades of mishandled cases of child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church.
articles.abstract: The move by a Harrisburg bishop comes ahead of a grand jury report expected to expose decades of mishandled cases of child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anticipating the release of a Pennsylvania grand jury report exposing decades of mishandled sexual abuse cases in the Roman Catholic Church, the bishop of Harrisburg on Wednesday ordered that the names of former bishops dating to the 1940s be stripped from church buildings.

articles.headline: Facebook Grapples With a Maturing Adversary in Election Meddling
articles.snippet: The influence campaign revealed on Tuesday is adapting and evolving to better disguise itself, which limits the social network’s approach to stopping it.
articles.abstract: The influence campaign revealed on Tuesday is adapting and evolving to better disguise itself, which limits the social network’s approach to stopping it.
articles.lead_paragraph: They covered their tracks, using software to camouflage their internet traffic. They created Facebook pages for anti-Trump culture warriors, Hispanic activists and fans of alternative medicine. And they organized protests in coordination with real-world political groups.

articles.headline: Mueller’s Digging Exposes Culture of Foreign Lobbying and Its Big Paydays
articles.snippet: Robert S. Mueller III’s investigations of foreign money flowing into Washington could be as much a part of his legacy as anything he unearths about Russian election interference.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Mueller III’s investigations of foreign money flowing into Washington could be as much a part of his legacy as anything he unearths about Russian election interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The mandate given to Robert S. Mueller III and his team was broad: to investigate not just Russian election interference but also any related crimes they might unearth. So when this group of seasoned prosecutors began rooting around Washington, they pounced on a ripe target — lobbyists taking millions of dollars from foreign governments.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Katie Benner

articles.headline: In Kashmir, Blood and Grief in an Intimate War: ‘These Bodies Are Our Assets’
articles.snippet: The Kashmir conflict, which once brought India and Pakistan to the brink of nuclear war, has become a bitterly personal, and mostly local, insurgency.
articles.abstract: The Kashmir conflict, which once brought India and Pakistan to the brink of nuclear war, has become a bitterly personal, and mostly local, insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: QASBAYAR, Kashmir — It was 9:30 p.m. when Sameer Tiger came to the door, a rifle slung over his shoulder.

articles.headline: Starbucks Teams Up With Alibaba on Coffee Delivery, as It Tries to Keep Its Throne in China
articles.snippet: Once unrivaled in China, Starbucks now faces fierce competition. To combat that, it is teaming up with one of China’s biggest tech giants.
articles.abstract: Once unrivaled in China, Starbucks now faces fierce competition. To combat that, it is teaming up with one of China’s biggest tech giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — For years, Starbucks was the undisputed king of coffee in China.

articles.headline: How Fake Influence Campaigns on Facebook Lured Real People
articles.snippet: Activists became entangled with fake accounts and pages on Facebook, leading to significant consequences for them as the company tried to clamp down.
articles.abstract: Activists became entangled with fake accounts and pages on Facebook, leading to significant consequences for them as the company tried to clamp down.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late June, after word emerged that the white supremacists who organized last year’s deadly “Unite the Right” march in Charlottesville, Va., had applied to hold an anniversary rally this month in Washington, a local political activist, Brendan Orsinger, saw that a Facebook event page had been created for a counterprotest.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: As Google Maps Renames Neighborhoods, Residents Fume
articles.snippet: Google’s digital maps have become the world’s default atlas and the arbiter of what neighborhoods are called, even when many residents disagree.
articles.abstract: Google’s digital maps have become the world’s default atlas and the arbiter of what neighborhoods are called, even when many residents disagree.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For decades, the district south of downtown and alongside San Francisco Bay here was known as either Rincon Hill, South Beach or South of Market. This spring, it was suddenly rebranded on Google Maps to a name few had heard: the East Cut.

articles.headline: Arrested, Jailed and Charged With a Felony. For Voting.
articles.snippet: Twelve people in a North Carolina county have been charged with voting illegally in the 2016 election. They face up to two years in prison.
articles.abstract: Twelve people in a North Carolina county have been charged with voting illegally in the 2016 election. They face up to two years in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAHAM, N.C. — Keith Sellars and his daughters were driving home from dinner at a Mexican restaurant last December when he was pulled over for running a red light. The officer ran a background check and came back with bad news for Mr. Sellars. There was a warrant out for his arrest.

articles.headline: Pope Francis Declares Death Penalty Unacceptable in All Cases
articles.snippet: The change in church teaching is likely to challenge Roman Catholic politicians, judges and officials who have argued that their church was not entirely opposed to capital punishment.
articles.abstract: The change in church teaching is likely to challenge Roman Catholic politicians, judges and officials who have argued that their church was not entirely opposed to capital punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis has declared the death penalty wrong in all cases, a definitive change in church teaching that is likely to challenge Catholic politicians, judges and officials who have argued that their church was not entirely opposed to capital punishment.
articles.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: ‘It Can Happen Even to Guys’: Ohio State Wrestlers Detail Abuse, Saying #UsToo
articles.snippet: Former Ohio State University wrestlers — athletes grappling with sexual abuse long buried in their memories — are taking their place in the #MeToo movement.
articles.abstract: Former Ohio State University wrestlers — athletes grappling with sexual abuse long buried in their memories — are taking their place in the #MeToo movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Nick Nutter, an All-American heavyweight wrestler at Ohio State turned professional martial arts fighter, sat watching the television last January as one by one, the young women, former gymnasts — some of them Olympians — took the stand in a courtroom in Michigan, and in wrenching testimony, detailed how their team doctor, Lawrence G. Nassar, had used his power to sexually abuse them.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Marc Tracy

articles.headline: Apple Is Worth $1,000,000,000,000. Two Decades Ago, It Was Almost Bankrupt.
articles.snippet: Steve Jobs said Apple was 90 days from bankruptcy in 1997. Now it is the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1 trillion.
articles.abstract: Steve Jobs said Apple was 90 days from bankruptcy in 1997. Now it is the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1 trillion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 1997, Apple was on the ropes. The Silicon Valley pioneer was being decimated by Microsoft and its many partners in the personal-computer market. It had just cut a third of its work force, and it was about 90 days from going broke, Apple’s late co-founder, Steve Jobs, later said.
